On the north side of the SW 1/4 of Sec. 26 in 1914, there was a 1914 stone (chamotte) on the ground. The month was covered with snow at this time, but the digging was away from the mouth quite far.

This away we could see the mouth quite far.

I think it was the China Building. That day, I went to Regina for the museum in 1905.

I heard the station (around 1905) would be built.

The hill facing the amphitheater is too high.

March 27, 1955

Dear Sir,

I am writing you a letter today. I have thought of something I thought to tell you about. This was in 1944.

On the north end of my property, the month was covered with snow. We could only see the top of earth. But by digging, we could see the inside of earth. We could see the moon quite far away.

I think it was Mr. Chas. Wooding that day. He said it was Regina for the museum in 1945.

I heard the station (Amund Quilling) said to have been destroyed on that date. It was no accident. Hundreds of people would have witnessed it, so it was a total loss.

The hill facing the south is another smaller hill during the fall and winter.

I think this might be of interest to you.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
Dear Sir,

I have been writing you a while ago, I have thought of something I forgot to tell you. On the north east side of sec. 32, T. 26, R. 11, 2 there was a homesteaded SW ¼ of SW ¼ of first peer of 1914. We could only see the eyes (more) the mouth was covered with two or three inches of earth & roots but by digging this away we could see the mouth quite plain.

I think it was Mrs. Glass Woodbury that dug it up & sent it to Regina for the museum in 1905.

I heard the doctor (Howard Duvall) said it had human sacrifices on that store & it was no situated hundreds of people could have witnessed it, as it was on top of the hill facing the south another smaller hill facing it like an amphitheater. I try to draw it.

I that this might be of interest to you.

Yours Truly,

Dear Sir,

Since writing you a while ago, I have thought of something I forgot to tell you. On the north side of sec 36, T26 R11 W4 there was a homestead (I homesteaded the SW ¼) in which we could only see the eyes more; the mouth was covered with three inches of earth. But by digging this away we could see the mouth quite plainly.

I think it was Mr. Elson Woodings that dug it up and sent it to Regina for the museum in 1905.

I heard the doctor (Dr. Woodings) said it had been sacrificed on that store, but it was not situated hundreds of feet from where it was found. The hill facing the mouth another smaller hill facing it like an amphitheater. You try to draw it.

I that this might be of interest to you.

Yours Truly,

Dear Sir,

Since writing you a while ago, I have thought of something I forgot to tell you.

On the north east 1/4 of sec 26, T.R. 2, there was a 1904 homestead (I homesteaded the SW 1/4) when I first came in 1905 we could only see the trees, the month was covered with two or three inches of snow but by digging thin away we could see the month quite plain.

I think it was Mr. Elton Wooding that dug it up and sent it to Regina for the museum in 1905.

I heard the Sister (Mound Dwellers) used to have human sacrifices on that store & it was situated hundreds of people could have witnessed it, so it was on top of the hill facing the south & another smaller hill facing it like an amphitheater. I try to draw it.

I that this might be of interest to you.

Yours Truly,

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914 and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.
